Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: looking at the process description, I can identify several key phases where questions could emerge: - R&D and component sourcing (Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Germany, US suppliers) - Manufacturing in Malaysia (24/7 shifts) - Logistics across global transport modes - Regional distribution strategies (just-in-time vs aggregated shipments) - End-to-consumer delivery with special cases (VIPs, recalls) - Digital systems and analytics - Compliance with multiple regulations

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: I need to understand what makes a question thought-provoking and open-ended in this context. The questions shouldnt have simple yes/no answers - they should invite deep analysis, critical thinking, and exploration of trade-offs. Since this is for a supply chain process with so many moving parts (multiple countries, different regulations, tech elements), I should focus on areas where complexities intersect: sustainability, risk management, technology integration, human factors, regulatory challenges, and strategic decisions.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: I should avoid questions that are too narrow or too obvious. For example, What is the lead time for components? would be too basic. Instead, I want questions that make someone think about implications - like how a supplier change in one region affects the whole chain, or what happens if a regulatory change in one country cascades.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The user emphasized discovering more insights, potential issues, strategies for improvement, and implications of various decisions. So each question should serve one of these purposes. Ill try to cover different angles: - Risk exposure (geopolitical, natural disasters) - Sustainability trade-offs (carbon footprint vs speed) - Technologys role (AI predictions vs real-world constraints) - Human elements (worker conditions in assembly plants) - Strategic decisions (when to use JIT vs bulk shipping)

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Let me brainstorm some questions first: 1. How might a geopolitical event (like a Taiwan semiconductor shortage) disrupt the entire chain beyond just component availability? 2. If the company switched to 100% recycled materials, would that increase costs more than the environmental benefits justify? 3. Could AI-driven demand forecasting prevent stockouts in high-demand markets while avoiding overstock in slower-moving ones? 4. What happens if a major logistics partner in Europe gets disrupted during customs clearance? 5. How would a sudden change in labor regulations in Malaysia affect production schedules?

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: I notice the process mentions strict quality assurance protocols and warranty considerations - thats a good area for questions about failure points. Also, the mention of carbon footprint suggests environmental concerns are important.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: I need to make sure all 20 are distinct and cover different aspects. I should avoid repeating themes. Let me mentally map out categories: - Geopolitical risks (4 questions) - Sustainability (3 questions) - Tech integration (4 questions) - Quality/safety (3 questions) - Human factors (2 questions) - Strategic trade-offs (4 questions)

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Ill aim for questions that: - Start with How, What if, In what ways, Why to keep them open - Reference specific elements from the description (e.g., just-in-time replenishment, OLED screens from South Korea) - Challenge assumptions (e.g., Is the current approach to carbon footprint truly sustainable?) - Consider long-term vs short-term impacts

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Pauses The user is probably a supply chain professional or student wanting to deepen their understanding. They might be preparing for a discussion, a report, or to test how well an LLM handles complex systems. So the questions should be sophisticated enough to be useful in real-world scenarios.

Name: Counterfactual Reasoning - PE
Text: Ill avoid questions that are too theoretical without practical relevance. For example, instead of Could quantum computing solve this? (too vague), Ill focus on actionable insights.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Final check: All questions must be open-ended (no yes/no), based on the given process, and thought-provoking. No SQL. Ready to compile.
